newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian oil exports hit by strike, not ethnic feud.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian oil exports hit by strike, not ethnic feud.

text.p: Royal Dutch Shell Group's Nigerian unit said on Tuesday it had declared force majeure on exports of its prized Bonny crude oil because of a strike by contractors.
A spokesman for the striking workers said they were demanding to be paid off because the company they worked for had been sold.
He told Reuters by telephone from Port Harcourt in the southeast that the dispute began after Ocean Inchcape Limited (O.I.L) of Britain was sold to U.S.-based Tidewater Inc.
"There are between 450-500 of us and some of us have been working for O.I.L. for more than 20 years," he said.
"We were demanding 10 years salary as pay-off but after long negotiation we have come down to one year but the management has not agreed to pay," he added.
A Shell spokesman said exports of gasoline-rich Bonny light crude oil were suspended indefinitely from Monday because of the strike. O.I.L. handles the berthing and loading of tankers.
"We have declared force majeure on Bonny exports with effect from yesterday," a Shell spokesman in Lagos said.
"This action was taken in response to a strike by workers of a contractor that operates support services for tankers berthing and loading at Bonny terminal."
Shell's Bonny output is about half of the roughly 950,000 barrels per day (bpd) it produces in Nigeria.
Shell is the biggest oil operator in Nigeria, pumping roughly half the entire output of Africa's leading oil producer.

The Anglo-Dutch company was widely expected to be hit by running communal clashes in the oil-producing Warri area in its western operational sector but it said the crisis so far had only a slight impact on its activities.
Its spokesman denied reports in Nigerian newspapers on Tuesday that the communal conflict in Warri had forced Shell to cut output there by 15 percent. "That is not true," he said.

The reports quoted Shell's Western division general manager Joshua Udofia as telling reporters in the troubled oil-producing city of Warri, where the company has its divisional headquarters, that production was down by 15 percent and staff evacuated.
"Mr Udofia is in Lagos and has not spoken to any reporter," the spokesman said.
He said the situation in the western division remained as it was at the weekend when one flow station was shut down with the loss of about 2,000 bpd of crude.
The trouble in Warri is over the relocation of the local council headquarters from a town belonging to the Ijaw tribe to that of the Itsekiris.
Gangs of armed youths from both sides have been fighting running battles in the creeks and the city. An estimated 60 people have been killed since April 12.
The latest killings were on Monday, when eight people were killed in two areas of Warri sacked by rampaging youths.
Nigerian newspapers reported that Warri was tense with some youths wearing military uniforms terrorising residents.
At the root of the crisis in Warri area is a rivalry among three tribes -- the Ijaws, the Itsekiris and the Urhobos -- who are each seeking more say in the affairs of the oil town.
